results.title: Uncle
results.creator_credit: VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne and Adam Elliot
results.brief_description: An award-winning short about a favoured Uncle who was a thoroughly ordinary and a thoroughly decent man. Peppered with wryly comic remembrances of a seventies childhood, ‘Uncle’ is a moving tribute to suburban eccentricity and familial loyalty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne and Adam Elliot

results.title: Uncle
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Sarah Watt and Adam Elliot
results.brief_description: An unnamed child, present only by an adult voice-over recounts the life of his uncle. How he survives his wife’s death, his dog’s death, and eventually his own inevitable end. The childlike innocence of the reflection is juxtaposed by the adult narration. Narrated by William McInnes and featuring John Flaus as the Uncle. The story is portrayed through animated clay figures. This film forms part of the autobiographical trilogy that includes “Uncle”, “Brother” and “Cousin”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Sarah Watt and Adam Elliot

results.title: Uncivilised (A)
results.brief_description: This is the story of Beatrice Lynn, a high society author, who heads into the wilds of northern Australia in search of an Aboriginal tribe ruled by a white king, Mara. Along the way she is kidnapped and taken through the bush, encountering pituri smugglers, and battling a killer before finally being sold to Mara. In the tradition of true melodramas a love conflict develops between the white chief and Beatrice and leads to an epic Chauvel finale. Filmed in North Queensland and Palm Island and featuring spectacular rainforest and river cinematography, director Chauvel made this film in an attempt to break into the American market. Censorship problems relating to nude swimming as well as violence were eventually overcome for the Australian release while a censored version was released on the overseas market.

results.title: Unbroken Spirit
results.creator_credit: Gittoes and Dalton Productions and George Gittoes
results.brief_description: The Tapp brothers of Kilarni Station, in the Northern Territory, and other stockmen talk about their way of life out in the bush mustering wild cattle.

results.title: Unbreakable [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Touchstone Pictures, Blinding Edge Pictures, Limited Edition Productions Inc., M Night Shyamalan, Barry Mendel and Sam Mercer
results.brief_description: Unbreakable is the follow-up film for M. Night Shyamalan after his worldwide hit “The Sixth sense”. Bruce Willis stars as David Dunn, an everyman character, a security guard and father of one, whose marriage is undergoing a crisis. David is the only survivor of a horrific train crash and miraculously is completely unharmed. Just after the crash David is befriended by Elijah Price aka Mr Glass (Samuel L. Jackson), a man suffering from the opposite syndrome - he is as fragile as cotton wool and has spent his entire life recovering from broken bones. Price runs a comic book store specialising in original comic book cells and has a genuine belief that superheroes exist in real life. These two men of opposing physical make-ups are brought together and discover that their destinies are strangely linked. David slowly comes to realise that he has extrasensory powers and superhuman strength that render him unbreakable. “Unbreakable” is a thriller, a classic good versus evil tale that explores the notion of supernatural forces at work in the world. Cast also includes Robin Wright Penn.

results.title: Una Filma di
results.brief_description: Designed to promote the Australian Universities Drama Festival. Shows the diverse reactions to an advertising poster ranging from hysteria and swooning to police action. Includes an early appearance by Max Gillies. Written by John Dawson. Music by George Tibbits.

results.title: Una Domenica d'Agosto = A Sunday in August
results.creator_credit: Sergio Amidei, Colonna Film and Luciano Emmer
results.brief_description:
A comedy-drama exploring the diverse social stratas in 1950s Italy as an unrelated group of people travel to Ostia Beach to escape Rome’s heat. During the course of the day their relationships are observed and their aspirations and destinies gradually revealed. Made on location in a Neo-Realist vein, using a partly amateur cast.

Credits: Producer, Sergio Amidei ; director, Luciano Emmer ; writer, Franco Brusati, Luciano Emmer, Cesare Zavattini, Giulio Macchi ; photography, Domenica Scala, Leonida Barboni, Ubaldo Marelli ; editing, Jolanda Benvenuti ; music, Roman Vlad.
Cast: Anna Baldini, Franco Interlenghi, Marcello Mastroianni, Elvy Lissia, Massimo Serato, Correda Verga, Ave Ninchi.

results.title: Un type comme moi ne devrait jamais mourir = A Guy Like Me Should Never Die
results.brief_description:
Leopold is an investment broker who is so opposed to war that he transfers his entire personal portfolio into chocolates, reasoning that this is a product that can never be turned to war-like use. One day, Leopold feels the need to break his old routine and leaves wife and career behind in order to meditate on the meaning of life.

Credits: Producer, Bernard Lenteric ; director, Michel Vianey ; writer, Michel Vianey ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Mort Schuman.
Cast: Jean-Michel Folon, Francine Racette, Bernard Fresson, Mort Schuman, Henri Garcin, Pierre Barouh, Bernadette Lafont.

results.title: Un Taxi Pour Tobruk = Taxi to Tobruk (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
In this WW II adventure, a band of French soldiers, separated from their unit, must escort a group of high-ranking German officers they have captured across the North African desert. Along the way a strange bond develops between the men, one of whom is Jewish. Just before they reach their destination, they are attacked by their own troops who do not recognize them. The films bears the usual trademarks of Michel Audiard’s rapide fire one liners.

Credits: Director, Denys de la Patelliere ; writers, Rene Havard, Michel Audiard ; photography, Marcel Grignon ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Lino Ventura, Charles Aznavour, Maurice Biraud, Hardy Kruger.
